Description: Scaraboid in glazed composition, probably mould-made; back in the shape of curled lion (?); underside bearing hieroglyphic inscription arranged horizontally, with from right to left, nefer-sign, falcon and ankh sign.
Curator's comments: This scaraboid was not seen by us. Its shape is very rare in the corpus of scaraboids from Naukratis. Even if Petrie illustrated the impression of a mould in the shape of a curled lion (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 7), he did not list it in his description of the moulds discovered at the site (Petrie 1886, 37). Such scaraboids were, nonetheless, likely produced locally in the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). For a scaraboid with a curled lion back from Naukratis, see 1888,0601.56 (published in Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 38). It is made out of pink paste. Though the hieroglyphic signs on its base could have just some magical value, it seems plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). The lion shape of the scaraboid itself can be associated with solar deties. Lions were used to write the name of Ra during the Late Period, as the lion is a phonetic equivalent Rw (De Wit 1951, 138ff). De Wit, C. 1951, Le rôle et le sens du lion dans l’Egypte ancienne, Leiden. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 110)
